text:
Coast to Coast icon Steve Gurney comes out of retirement for inaugural event AUDREY MALONE Last updated 19:52, October 10 2015 FAIRFAX NZ 
Coast to Coast legend Steve Gurney crossing the finishing line at Saturday's Rakaia Salmon Run. 
Coast to Coast legend Steve Gurney came out of retirement for the inaugural Rakaia Salmon Run multi-sports event because he thought it would be an easy run against some oldies. 
"I'm 52. I saw there was a 50-plus age category, so there's a reasonable chance, I thought I might be able to bring a first place but not train," Gurney said at the completion of his race, before the results were known. 
"But those old buggers go bloody hard. They really pushed me. I don't know if I have won it." 
However, when the times for Saturday's race were collated, Gurney was victorious in that "old-bugger" section. 
The kayak, cycle and run event was held around the Rakaia Domain, a walkway, a farm and on the Rakaia River. 
"I had to come out of retirement for the inaugural event. You only get the chance to do an inaugural event once. And I have never raced on the Rakaia before. It's a special thing." 
Gurney has won the gruelling Coast to Coast nine times but, was "retired" from the world of multi-sports - in part because he hates running. 
Three kilometres into the rugged 13km run, which saw participants clambering over the river bed, Gurney tore his Achilles' tendon. He battled through, not worried if it would affect him getting a good time. 
"It's not about times. It's about placing and winning my category." 
He noticed the spectators were gunning for him. They were cheering for "their person" to take him on, he said. 
"I would hear them yelling [at the person they were supporting] to get me. A bit cheeky. I'm an old man now, so it's not really being competitive is it." 
Whether or not he would do it all again next year, Gurney wasn't entirely sure. 
"It was a great race and I wanted the opportunity to have a go on the Rakaia." - Stuff
